posts.name: Jonny Dee
posts.cooked:
bjoel:

WhatsApp is releasing the ability to lock individual chats behind biometric/device pin.

I doubt we’ll ever see sth. like that in Signal. For the same reasons why we won’t get an app password lock (back again).

Signal’s threat model assumes the OS already provides trusted security measures which are supposed to be sufficient. Especially, when it comes to authorized access to the Signal app.If someone is able to unlock your phone and gains access to the app he is as well authorized to read the chats and actively take part in conversations. No need to have an additional PIN or password that would allow using the app only when the user knows it, too.

Given this threat model a password for locking individual chats doesn’t make sense.

That said, I would love to see both a password lock for the Signal app itself and one for specific chats.

posts.name: Maksym Kozub
posts.cooked:
JonnyDee:

Signal’s threat model assumes the OS already provides trusted security measures which are supposed to be sufficient.

I would say that this assumption can be true e.g. on Google Pixel phones, where it is possible to hve multiple user profiles under Android. However, most Android phones do not have such feature, and, as mentioned in another message in this topic, there may be situations where several members of a poor family use one Andoid phone as one Android user. In my view, it makes sense to enable them to protect their Signal data from each other.

posts.name: Maksym Kozub
posts.cooked:
TeeJay82:

As soon as they have shared contacts this will no longer work.

What do you mean when saying “This will no longer work”?
Imagine there is an Android phone used by Alice and her husband Bob, under the same Android account. Both Alice and Bob see the contact list (be it local, Google contacts, etc.). One of the contacts is Carol, Alice’s sister; both Alice and Bob can call Carol on the phone or exchange SMS messages with her. However, there is also SIgnal installed on Alice and Bob’s phone and on Carol’s one. Alice would like to chat with Carol on Signal without Bob seeing those chats. Basically, in this topic, we are discussing a feature whereby Alice would have a Signal password/PIN/whatever, so that Bob will not be able to see Alice’s conversations with Carol on SIgnal even when he has the phone in his hands. What does it have to do with Carol being a shared contact for Alice and Bob?
What if Bob wants to exchange messages with Carol as well?

posts.name: Maksym Kozub
posts.cooked:
TeeJay82:

What if Bob wants to exchange messages with Carol as well?

If the device does not support multiple user accounts (i.e., it is not a Google Pixel etc.), then it is impossible to have several Signal instances, and your question is not a software problem but a family relationship problem, one of reaching an agreement between family members, etc. In that situation, Alice and Bob will have to decide between themselves who is the “control user”, “main user”, etc., of their smartphone, and such “control user” will be the only one entitled (not technically but based on an agreement within the family!) to install and use Signal on that phone.
If they do not reach an agreement, they may decide to divorce, but this is, again, not a problem of software features :).

Maksym_Kozub:

your question is not a software problem but a family relationship problem, one of reaching an agreement between family members, etc.

As is your use case.

posts.name: Maksym Kozub
posts.cooked:
TeeJay82:

As is your use case.

I do not fully get your point. First of all, this is not “my” use case. One smartphone being used by several family members was first mentioned by @ponytail; I just referred to it in my first comment, and added some more details to that use case. Of course, that situation itself is not a software problem. However, basically speaking, software is developed to satisfy some needs and provide solutions to [non-software] problems, be it in accounting, manufacturing, secure communications, etc. In the situation where one smartphone is used by several people, there [potentially] exists is a software-based way to satisfy the need for privacy for at least one user. Who will be that “control user”, whether an agreement between those users is possible, etc., is, of course, not something to be decided by software itself. But if those users can come to an agreement, then such feature will be useful to them.
I would also like to be able to lock certain conversations, especially notes.

Oh dear, how did I miss this thread?

Should I just not use my phone while I’m walking on the street?

No, you should be attentive and watch your surroundings when you walk down the street, not use your phone. You might get hurt, hit by a car or bike, bump into someone else, etc. Phone use can wait until you are stopped and/or sitting down somewhere safe to do so.

Please don’t do that. When you deem her old enough to have her phone, that’s when she can use Signal. Children should never use their parents’ phones. As you say yourself, you may have things there you don’t want her to see, for one.

If the device does not support multiple user accounts (i.e., it is not a Google Pixel etc.), then it is impossible to have several Signal instances

Just as a technical comment:

There are other Android phones that do support multiple accounts as this is a general Android feature that could technically be enabled in any brand:

Android Open Source Project

Support multiple users  |  Android Open Source Project

I’m not sure if it is truly possible to run different signal instances though, since the installations on different accounts can sometimes conflict. Technically, they shouldn’t, but sometimes they still do in my experience. I wanted to try it out once, but Signal started behaving abnormally, so i stopped before completing registration on the second account because I didn’t want to lose data on the first one.
